<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 279, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 186, 907, 202]]<|/det|>
0625/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 208, 907, 223]]<|/det|>
May/June 2013  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 229, 907, 243]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 544, 293]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 343, 235, 358]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 358, 599, 373]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 373, 892, 403]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 416]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 430, 892, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 505]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 534]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 534, 467, 549]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 744, 91]]<|/det|> A student measures the length of a rod XY by holding it next to a metre rule. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 98, 700, 198]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 208, 504, 227]]<|/det|> The student writes down the length as \(94.8 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 237, 348, 255]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 266, 134, 284]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 266, 322, 284]]<|/det|> The value is correct. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 292, 134, 310]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 292, 579, 310]]<|/det|> The value is incorrect because it should be \(95.2 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 317, 134, 336]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 317, 625, 336]]<|/det|> The value is incorrect because it should be in millimetres. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 344, 134, 363]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 344, 920, 377]]<|/det|> The value is incorrect because the student should subtract the reading for end Y from the reading for end X. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 402, 94, 421]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 402, 920, 437]]<|/det|> A heavy metal ball falls vertically downwards through air past four equally spaced levels J, K, L and M. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 444, 635, 617]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 630, 638, 648]]<|/det|> The times taken to fall from one level to the next are measured. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 660, 667, 679]]<|/det|> Where is the speed of the ball greatest and which time is shortest? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 689, 529, 836]]<|/det|>
speed is
greatest between		time is
shortest between
AJ and KJ and K
BJ and KL and M
CL and MJ and K
DL and ML and M

density of the airmovement of the air

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 581, 91]]<|/det|> An old and expensive steel watch becomes magnetised. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 732, 121]]<|/det|> The owner wants to use the watch again. He must demagnetise the watch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 415, 150]]<|/det|> What is the **best** method to do this? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 160, 134, 179]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 160, 384, 179]]<|/det|> Heat it until it glows red hot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 186, 134, 203]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 186, 390, 203]]<|/det|> Pass direct current though it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 212, 131, 230]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 212, 727, 230]]<|/det|> Place it in a plastic bag and put the bag in hot water for several hours. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 238, 133, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 237, 796, 256]]<|/det|> Place it in a solenoid that carries alternating current and then slowly remove it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 284, 106, 303]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 282, 922, 317]]<|/det|> Three charged balls, P, Q and R are suspended by insulating threads. Ball P is negatively charged. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 384, 346]]<|/det|> Ball Q is brought close to ball P. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 355, 635, 437]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 448, 421, 467]]<|/det|> Ball Q is now brought close to ball R. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 476, 561, 560]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 573, 500, 592]]<|/det|> What are the charges on ball Q and on ball R? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 603, 401, 732]]<|/det|>
ball Qball R
Apositivepositive
Bpositivenegative
Cnegativepositive
Dnegativenegative

All the lamps are lit. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 496, 621, 631]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 544, 663]]<|/det|> Lamp Y is removed by unscrewing it from its holder. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 674, 336, 692]]<|/det|> What happens to lamp Z? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 702, 134, 721]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 702, 339, 721]]<|/det|> It goes out completely. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 730, 133, 747]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 730, 415, 747]]<|/det|> It becomes dimmer but stays lit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 756, 133, 775]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 756, 390, 775]]<|/det|> It stays the same brightness. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 784, 133, 802]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 784, 319, 801]]<|/det|> It becomes brighter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 824, 107]]<|/det|> Each branch of a domestic circuit often includes a circuit-breaker. This protects the much current flows in the circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 777, 136]]<|/det|> In which wire is the circuit-breaker placed and what does it do when it operates? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 145, 751, 275]]<|/det|>
circuit-breaker inwhen the circuit-breaker operates it
Alive wiredisconnects the circuit
Blive wirereduces the current to a safe value (not zero)
Cneutral wiredisconnects the circuit
Dneutral wirereduces the current to a safe value (not zero)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 301, 106, 320]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 660, 320]]<|/det|> A student wants to make a transformer to step 12 V down to 6.0 V. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 331, 714, 350]]<|/det|> She winds 60 turns of wire around an iron core as shown in the diagram. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 358, 745, 534]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 547, 796, 567]]<|/det|> How many turns of wire should she wind on the secondary coil of her transformer? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 134, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 575, 168, 594]]<|/det|> 5 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 575, 298, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 575, 336, 594]]<|/det|> 30 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 575, 470, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 575, 505, 594]]<|/det|> 60 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 575, 635, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 575, 688, 594]]<|/det|> 120 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 621, 106, 640]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 621, 680, 640]]<|/det|> A toy railway engine is driven around a track by a d.c. electric motor. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 651, 504, 670]]<|/det|> How can the speed of the motor be increased? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 680, 133, 698]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 680, 505, 698]]<|/det|> Use a motor made with fewer turns of wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 707, 133, 725]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 707, 373, 725]]<|/det|> Use a smaller d.c. voltage. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 734, 133, 752]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 734, 452, 752]]<|/det|> Use a stronger magnet in the motor. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 761, 133, 778]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 761, 526, 778]]<|/det|> Use the supply with its connections reversed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 755, 92]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows an experiment to demonstrate electromagnetic induction.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 97, 732, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 375, 735, 395]]<|/det|>
X and Y are joined, in turn, by four wires, each made of a different material.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 406, 670, 426]]<|/det|>
Each wire is then moved quickly downwards between the magnets.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 437, 660, 456]]<|/det|>
Which material will **not** give rise to an induced current in the wire?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 466, 240, 485]]<|/det|>
A aluminium

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 491, 213, 510]]<|/det|>
B copper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 517, 188, 536]]<|/det|>
C iron

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 543, 201, 562]]<|/det|>
D nylon

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 588, 106, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 587, 670, 606]]<|/det|>
A beam of cathode rays passes between two charged metal plates.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 616, 695, 689]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 707, 616, 727]]<|/det|>
What happens to the beam as it passes between the plates?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 736, 134, 755]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 737, 386, 755]]<|/det|>
It is deflected into the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 761, 134, 780]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 761, 403, 780]]<|/det|>
It is deflected out of the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 787, 134, 807]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 787, 490, 807]]<|/det|>
It is deflected towards the negative plate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 814, 133, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 814, 484, 833]]<|/det|>
It is deflected towards the positive plate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 620, 92]]<|/det|>
A radiation detector is placed close to a source of \(\beta\) -particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 856, 123]]<|/det|>
Aluminium sheets of increasing thickness are placed between the source and the detector

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[248, 128, 745, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 291, 920, 327]]<|/det|>
Eventually a sheet which is \(2.0 \text{cm}\) thick is used. The reading on the detector decreases, but does not fall to zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 336, 432, 356]]<|/det|>
Why does the reading not fall to zero?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 365, 134, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 365, 618, 384]]<|/det|>
Some of the \(\beta \text{-particles}\) go round the edges of the sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 393, 131, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 393, 475, 411]]<|/det|>
The detector is too close to the source.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 420, 131, 439]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 420, 515, 439]]<|/det|>
There is always some background radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 447, 133, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 446, 692, 465]]<|/det|>
The sheet can never be thick enough to absorb all the \(\beta\) -particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 490, 104, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 490, 509, 509]]<|/det|>
A nuclide is represented by the notation shown.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 515, 532, 565]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{P}_{X}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 574, 598, 594]]<|/det|>
How many nucleons are there in one atom of this nuclide?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 603, 131, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 603, 166, 621]]<|/det|>
P
